text:
They’re THE MS person. 
I think there was a Twitter thread started a couple of days ago that sparked a
discussion about this. I’m guessing she’s reaching out to the broader audience
to collect info. 
But, yes, the answer should be pretty obvious. I may have looked at those log
files once for fun and learning, but never again until things blow up.

metadata.topic: RE: Do you look at update logs?
metadata.subject: [patchmanagement] RE: Do you look at update logs?

metadata.email_text_original:
RE: Do you look at update logs? 
You don't often get email from mjudd@360smartnet.com. Learn why this is
important [https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification] 
They’re THE MS person.  😃
I think there was a Twitter thread started a couple of days ago that sparked a
discussion about this.  I’m guessing she’s reaching out to the broader audience
to collect info. 
But, yes, the answer should be pretty obvious.  I may have looked at those log
files once for fun and learning, but never again until things blow up. 
From: 'Erno, Cynthia M (ITS)' via PatchManagement
<patchmanagement@googlegroups.com>
Sent: Wednesday, November 8, 2023 3:28 AM
To: patchmanagement@googlegroups.com
Subject: [patchmanagement] RE: Do you look at update logs? 
All the time.  Have over 6,000 servers to manage.  Windows update logs help to
show what may be causing the issue behind patches not being applied. 
Please tell me this isn’t an MS person asking this question.  Because I feel I
just stated the obvious. 
Cynthia Erno 
From: 'Susan Bradley' via PatchManagement <patchmanagement@googlegroups.com>
Sent: Tuesday, November 7, 2023 6:22 PM
To: patchmanagement@googlegroups.com
Subject: [patchmanagement] Do you look at update logs? 
ATTENTION: This email came from an external source. Do not open attachments or
click on links from unknown senders or unexpected emails.
